1.QUESTION: Host factors more strongly related to diseases is/are

OPTION.A: Age
OPTION.B: Marital status
OPTION.C: Sex
OPTION.D: Occupation
OPTION.E: Race

1.EXPLANATION: Age, sex, occupation, and race influence susceptibility; marital status does not.

2.QUESTION: Indirect transmission of communicable disease occurs through following sources except

OPTION.A: Touch
OPTION.B: Air
OPTION.C: Water
OPTION.D: Vector
OPTION.E: Trans-placental

2.EXPLANATION: Touch is direct contact; the rest are indirect transmission modes.

3.QUESTION: The following statement about disease carriers is/are true?

OPTION.A: A carrier is always an infected person
OPTION.B: Some non-communicable diseases have carrier state
OPTION.C: A carrier can transmit the disease during the incubation period
OPTION.D: A only is correct
OPTION.E: All of the above are correct

3.EXPLANATION: Carriers transmit disease during incubation; not all carriers are always infected, and non-communicable diseases do not have carriers.

4.QUESTION: With respect to the screening test

OPTION.A: It is valid if it gives a good preliminary indication of which individuals have the disease
OPTION.B: Its yield refers to the amount of the disease it can detect in the population
OPTION.C: Its reliability depends on its repeatability with consistency of results
OPTION.D: It is the basic tool of the screening programme
OPTION.E: It does not have to be acceptable if it is relatively easy and safe

4.EXPLANATION: Screening must be acceptable to the population; the other statements correctly describe screening tests.

5.QUESTION: The following are true about Leprosy

OPTION.A: More prevalent in India and tropical Africa than Europe
OPTION.B: Tuberculoid leprosy has higher bacterial index than lepromatous leprosy
OPTION.C: Bacterial and morphological indices are used to monitor response to treatment
OPTION.D: Mitsuda reaction occurs earlier than Fernandez
OPTION.E: Rifampicin, Dapsone, and Clofazimine are used in treatment

5.EXPLANATION: Lepromatous leprosy has higher bacterial index; Mitsuda reaction is a delayed hypersensitivity test, not earlier than Fernandez.

6.QUESTION: The following STI's are caused by matched organisms

OPTION.A: Lymphogranuloma venereum / Chlamydia trachomatis
OPTION.B: Chancroid / Treponema pallidum
OPTION.C: Granuloma inguinale / Gardnerella vaginalis
OPTION.D: Genital warts / Human immunodeficiency virus
OPTION.E: Non-specific urethritis / Ureaplasma urealyticum

6.EXPLANATION: Correct STI-organism pairs are lymphogranuloma venereum and Chlamydia, non-specific urethritis and Ureaplasma; others are mismatched.

7.QUESTION: The following are modes of transmission of the corresponding arthropod disease/agent

OPTION.A: African trypanosomiasis - rubbing feces of reduviid bug
OPTION.B: Chaga's disease - biting of Glossina fly
OPTION.C: Yellow fever - ingestion of Cyclops from water
OPTION.D: Filariasis - inhalation of Wuchereria bancrofti
OPTION.E: Dengue fever - biting of Aedes mosquito

7.EXPLANATION: African trypanosomiasis is transmitted by Glossina; Chagas disease via reduviid bug feces; yellow fever via Aedes mosquito, not ingestion; filariasis via mosquito bite.

8.QUESTION: The following are situations in which transmission of zoonotic disease can occur except

OPTION.A: Animal contaminates human environment
OPTION.B: Vector transmits infection from animal to humans
OPTION.C: Inoculation through animal bite
OPTION.D: Humans use the animal for food
OPTION.E: Only A & B are correct

8.EXPLANATION: Zoonotic transmission occurs via contamination, vector, or bite; consumption is a separate consideration.

9.QUESTION: The following are correctly matched with their specific developments in occupational health

OPTION.A: Percival Pott - chimney sweeping and cancer of the scrotum
OPTION.B: Paracelsus - toxicity due to mercury and sulphur
OPTION.C: Sir Thomas Legg - Pioneer occupational physician in USA
OPTION.D: Gergius Agricola - Abdominal colic and lead poisoning
OPTION.E: George Baker - described health problems in mines

9.EXPLANATION: Sir Thomas Legg is not US-based; Agricola studied mining but not specifically lead poisoning.

10.QUESTION: The following tatements about inorganic lead poisoning is/are true

OPTION.A: Abdominal colic is a chronic symptom
OPTION.B: Encephalopathy is the commonest presentation
OPTION.C: Increased urinary lead above 0.2 mg/l is observed
OPTION.D: Anaemia with punctate basophilic is not commonly seen
OPTION.E: There is increased urinary coproporphyrin

10.EXPLANATION: Encephalopathy is rare; abdominal colic, elevated lead and coproporphyrin are classic features.

11.QUESTION: Legumes are deficient in

OPTION.A: Methionine and lysine
OPTION.B: Methionine and cysteine
OPTION.C: Lysine and tryptophan
OPTION.D: Tryptophan and cysteine
OPTION.E: Lysine and cysteine

11.EXPLANATION: Legumes are low in sulfur-containing amino acids: methionine and cysteine.

12.QUESTION: Which of the following will provide nutritionally adequate diet

OPTION.A: Beans and corn
OPTION.B: Pap with soy milk
OPTION.C: Moi-Moi and pap
OPTION.D: Spaghetti with carrot and green pepper
OPTION.E: Only A and C

12.EXPLANATION: Combining legumes with cereals provides complete proteins; vegetable alone or pap with soy milk does not suffice.

13.QUESTION: Zinc deficiencies are associated with the following EXCEPT

OPTION.A: Immune deficiency
OPTION.B: Diarrhoea
OPTION.C: Discoloration of skin
OPTION.D: A and B only
OPTION.E: A and C only

13.EXPLANATION: Zinc deficiency causes immune dysfunction and diarrhea; skin discoloration is less commonly associated.

14.QUESTION: Anti-nutrients in legumes include

OPTION.A: Phytates
OPTION.B: Trypsin and chymotrypsin inhibitors
OPTION.C: Tannins
OPTION.D: Haemagglutinins
OPTION.E: Only B and D

14.EXPLANATION: Legumes contain phytates, tannins, protease inhibitors, and lectins (haemagglutinins).

15.QUESTION: Carbohydrates in the diet supply

OPTION.A: 45-65% of total energy intake
OPTION.B: 60-75% of total water intake
OPTION.C: 20-35% of total fat intake
OPTION.D: 50-70% of total fibre intake
OPTION.E: None of the above

15.EXPLANATION: Carbohydrates supply 45â€“65% of energy; other options are incorrect.

16.QUESTION: The following oils are rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids

OPTION.A: Sunflower oil
OPTION.B: Soybean oil
OPTION.C: Cottonseed oil
OPTION.D: Olive oil
OPTION.E: Palm oil

16.EXPLANATION: Olive oil is monounsaturated, palm oil is saturated; others are PUFA-rich.

17.QUESTION: The underlying causes of malnutrition include

OPTION.A: Inadequate levels of household food security
OPTION.B: Inadequate care of children and women
OPTION.C: Low education levels and information
OPTION.D: War, conflicts, and political instability
OPTION.E: Insufficient health services

17.EXPLANATION: All listed factors contribute to malnutrition.

18.QUESTION: Sick-role is

OPTION.A: A form of behavior deemed appropriate to those perceived as ill
OPTION.B: The individual is not responsible for their illness
OPTION.C: Exemption from normal obligations until well
OPTION.D: When the ill person seeks professional help
OPTION.E: When the sick person consults a relation or friend

18.EXPLANATION: Sick-role includes all listed behavioral and societal expectations.

19.QUESTION: Medical Sociology is interested in

OPTION.A: What people think/believe and do about health and illness how the beliefs affect their health
OPTION.B: Patient-doctor relationship
OPTION.C: Patient care management
OPTION.D: Hospital organizations
OPTION.E: Care of the handicapped

19.EXPLANATION: Medical sociology covers all aspects of social behavior related to health care.

20.QUESTION: Ascribed status refers to the following

OPTION.A: Sex
OPTION.B: Age
OPTION.C: Profession
OPTION.D: Social class
OPTION.E: Husband

20.EXPLANATION: Ascribed status is assigned at birth or involuntarily (sex, age, social class). Profession and marital status are achieved.

21.QUESTION: Concerning the term 'Disease Vector'

OPTION.A: Refers to agents that carry and transmit infectious pathogens into other living organisms
OPTION.B: Agents could be an inanimate medium of infection such as dust particles
OPTION.C: All agents regarded as vectors are organisms, such as intermediate parasites or microbes
OPTION.D: Means of control can be biological
OPTION.E: Pests may transmit diseases but cannot have a nuisance value

21.EXPLANATION: Vectors are living organisms transmitting disease; inanimate objects are fomites; pests can have nuisance value.

22.QUESTION: Concerning 'Disease Transmission'

OPTION.A: Arthropods form a major group of pathogen vectors
OPTION.B: Haematophagous agents feed on blood at some or all stages of their lives
OPTION.C: Diatomine bugs transmit Trypanosoma causing Chagas disease
OPTION.D: Means of control can be biological
OPTION.E: Some plants and fungi act as vectors for various pathogens

22.EXPLANATION: All statements are correct; plants/fungi can carry pathogens.

23.QUESTION: Food hygiene

OPTION.A: WHO assists member states in promoting safe food handling
OPTION.B: Its efforts does not require intersectoral collaboration
OPTION.C: Involves conditions and measures necessary to ensure safety only during servicing of food
OPTION.D: Persons with wounds, otitis media or skin infections should not handle food or utensils
OPTION.E: Food handlers are to undergo medical check at least twice/year.

23.EXPLANATION: Food hygiene requires collaboration and safety at all stages.

24.QUESTION: Housing

OPTION.A: Overcrowding is a potentially very important factor that has bearing on the risks of home accident.
OPTION.B: Physical overcrowding occurs when two persons over six years of age of same gender obliged to sleep in same room
OPTION.C: Healthy or unhealthy housing is related to exposure to toxins and environmental factors
OPTION.D: Is only the physical structure providing shelter
OPTION.E: Statutory overcrowding occurs when Room or Space Standard is contravened

24.EXPLANATION: Housing includes environmental quality; not just structure.

25.QUESTION: Direct effects of radiation pollution include all except

OPTION.A: Famine and drought due to poor agricultural output and lack of potable water
OPTION.B: Economic loss and poverty due to poor agricultural output
OPTION.C: Disorder in the ecosystem and its attendant effects
OPTION.D: Global warming, climate change and all its effects
OPTION.E: Civil strife due to fighting over available land and water

25.EXPLANATION: Radiation directly causes health/ecosystem effects; global warming is unrelated.

26.QUESTION: Qualities of a good sewage disposal system include

OPTION.A: Must not pollute surface soil or water (surface or underground).
OPTION.B: Must not be sightly or smelly.
OPTION.C: There must not be any handling whatsoever of fresh faeces.
OPTION.D: Method should be culturally acceptable to the community.
OPTION.E: Must be situated at least 50meters downhill from water source

26.EXPLANATION: Sewage should be hygienic and culturally appropriate; smell is an issue to manage but not disqualifying.

27.QUESTION: Factors affecting waste management include

OPTION.A: Economic activities
OPTION.B: Climatic and seasonal changes
OPTION.C: Physical characteristics/topography
OPTION.D: Social and religious custom
OPTION.E: Finance and budgetary limitations

27.EXPLANATION: All listed factors influence waste management effectiveness.

28.QUESTION: The road to health card for a child

OPTION.A: Should be kept by the health worker
OPTION.B: This is a relatively cheap and effective measure in the promotion of health and in the early detection and prevention of disease in infants and children.
OPTION.C: It can also facilitate advantageous family spacing
OPTION.D: It serves as a record of birth data, growth in mass, immunization, neurological development and episodes of illness only
OPTION.E: Shows other useful information apart from anthropometric values

28.EXPLANATION: Health card documents multiple aspects of child health and development.

29.QUESTION: The following are live attenuated vaccines

OPTION.A: Yellow fever
OPTION.B: Sabine vaccine
OPTION.C: Rubella vaccine
OPTION.D: Pertussis vaccine
OPTION.E: Salk vaccine

29.EXPLANATION: Pertussis and Salk polio vaccines are inactivated; others are live attenuated.

30.QUESTION: The activities of international health include

OPTION.A: health regulations
OPTION.B: control of international travels
OPTION.C: control of the spread of international diseases only
OPTION.D: vaccination against typhoid
OPTION.E: Food control

30.EXPLANATION: Vaccination against specific diseases like typhoid is national, not international health activity.

31.QUESTION: The following are publications of the World Health Organization

OPTION.A: Weekly epidemiological report
OPTION.B: World Health Policy and Planning
OPTION.C: World Health Report
OPTION.D: Journal of Public Health in Developing countries
OPTION.E: World health bulletin

31.EXPLANATION: D is not a WHO publication.

32.QUESTION: The following are comprehensive indicators that measure Health in any community

OPTION.A: Proportional mortality indicator
OPTION.B: Expectation of life
OPTION.C: Maternal and infant mortality rates
OPTION.D: Number of females
OPTION.E: Crude birth rate.

32.EXPLANATION: Number of females is not a health indicator.

33.QUESTION: The following requirements are to be satisfied by the health information system according to the WHO

OPTION.A: The system should be grouped and specific based
OPTION.B: Feedback components absolutely necessary
OPTION.C: The system should agglomerate data carefully
OPTION.D: Financial statistics is very important
OPTION.E: The system should express information imaginatively

33.EXPLANATION: Health information must be accurate and functional; imaginative presentation is not a requirement.

34.QUESTION: Concerning the Sustainable Development Goals

OPTION.A: The goals are a United States Initiative.
OPTION.B: The Sustainable Development Goals are officially known as Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda
OPTION.C: There are 19 Sustainable Development Goals and 167 targets.
OPTION.D: The Goals were adopted on 25 September 2015
OPTION.E: The second Sustainable Development Goal is zero hunger

34.EXPLANATION: SDGs are UN initiatives; there are 17 goals, not 19.

35.QUESTION: The following is true about routine immunization in Nigeria except

OPTION.A: PPV is given at 6, 10 and 14 weeks
OPTION.B: OPV is given at birth, 6 and 14 weeks
OPTION.C: Measles and Yellow fever are given at 9 months
OPTION.D: BCG can only be given at birth
OPTION.E: Vitamin A is only given to children under age 1 year

35.EXPLANATION: PPV schedule is incorrect; Vitamin A is given to older children too.

36.QUESTION: Healthcare financing options include all the following

OPTION.A: Life insurance premium
OPTION.B: Community contributions
OPTION.C: Payment for health services rendered
OPTION.D: National Health Insurance Scheme
OPTION.E: Only D is correct

36.EXPLANATION: All listed options are forms of healthcare financing.

37.QUESTION: Regarding health education and health information

OPTION.A: Health education and Health Information are the same in real terms.
OPTION.B: Health education refers to health related facts.
OPTION.C: Until there is a change in behavior, health information is not said to have taken place.
OPTION.D: An individual who is informed about health related facts but fails to change his/her behaviour is merely health informed not health educated
OPTION.E: There is nothing like Health information.

37.EXPLANATION: Health education focuses on behavior change; information alone is insufficient.

38.QUESTION: The following is are part(s) of the planning cycle except

OPTION.A: Selection of strategies
OPTION.B: Prioritization of needs
OPTION.C: Activity scheduling
OPTION.D: Resource specification
OPTION.E: Stratification of key members

38.EXPLANATION: Selection of strategies is part of planning; stratification of members is not standard terminology.

39.QUESTION: The following are component of Health information system

OPTION.A: Demography and vital statistics.
OPTION.B: Community diagnosis.
OPTION.C: Health status of individuals.
OPTION.D: Financial statistics
OPTION.E: Health management and planning.

39.EXPLANATION: Financial statistics are not a core component of HIS.

40.QUESTION: The following are characteristics of research except

OPTION.A: It demands a clear statement of the problem and a purpose.
OPTION.B: It requires a study design which will be specified in a proposal prior to its implementation
OPTION.C: It builds on existing data using both the positive and negative findings.
OPTION.D: New data is collected as required, and organised in such a way that they answer the original research question.
OPTION.E: It is usually exploratory

40.EXPLANATION: Research can be exploratory but not all research is; main characteristics are systematic and planned.

41.QUESTION: The following statements about biostatistics is correct

OPTION.A: It is applied to biological sciences
OPTION.B: It is usually inductive in nature
OPTION.C: It usually follows probability theory
OPTION.D: Inductive uses specifics to apply on the general
OPTION.E: It is of little use in the development of health care policy

41.EXPLANATION: Biostatistics is essential for healthcare policy and planning.

42.QUESTION: The following requirements are to be satisfied by the health information system according to WHO

OPTION.A: The system should be grouped and specific based
OPTION.B: Feedback components absolutely necessary
OPTION.C: The system should agglomerate data carefully
OPTION.D: Financial statistics is very important
OPTION.E: The system should express information imaginatively

42.EXPLANATION: Imaginative expression is not a formal requirement.

43.QUESTION: The following variables can be classified as an ordered poly-chotomous categorical variable except

OPTION.A: Blood group of individuals
OPTION.B: Skin colour measurements
OPTION.C: Social class of individuals
OPTION.D: Chlamydia test result
OPTION.E: Cervical smear result in selected women

43.EXPLANATION: Blood group and Chlamydia test result are nominal; others are ordered categorical.

44.QUESTION: The following statements about data on the nominal scale are/is correct

OPTION.A: It follows an order in some cases
OPTION.B: It is classified by some quantities it posses
OPTION.C: It may involve arithmetic computations
OPTION.D: It is classificatory in nature
OPTION.E: Ethnicity is an example of a variable in this class

44.EXPLANATION: Nominal data are purely classificatory; ethnicity is an example.

45.QUESTION: Concerning the bar chart

OPTION.A: Simple bar chart are the commoner type
OPTION.B: It can be presented in column or horizontal bars
OPTION.C: Component bar charts is used to compare two or more items
OPTION.D: The heights of the bars are directly proportional to the values of the items
OPTION.E: Column or horizontal bar charts are used in time series presentations

45.EXPLANATION: Time series usually uses line or histogram charts, not simple bar charts.

46.QUESTION: These statements about the mean is not true

OPTION.A: Geometric mean is used usually for observations on a logarithm scale
OPTION.B: Mean > median, the distribution is skewed to the left
OPTION.C: Mean < mode, the distribution is skewed to the right
OPTION.D: In bimodal the mean is usually equal to the median
OPTION.E: Mean cannot be calculated if a single observation is missing

46.EXPLANATION: Mean can be calculated even with missing values using appropriate methods.

47.QUESTION: These characteristics and uses of the mode as a type of summary indices is/are correct

OPTION.A: It is not affected by outliers
OPTION.B: May have multiple values in sizable number of cases
OPTION.C: Not affected by fluctuations of sampling
OPTION.D: Does not exist if all values in a set occur with the same frequency
OPTION.E: It often occurs in unimodal form

47.EXPLANATION: Mode can vary with sample; statement C is incorrect.

48.QUESTION: In choosing significant test for differences between groups, the following test statistics can be used for unpaired test

OPTION.A: Sign test
OPTION.B: Chi-square test
OPTION.C: Fishers exact
OPTION.D: T-test
OPTION.E: F-test

48.EXPLANATION: All can be used depending on data type.

49.QUESTION: The following assumptions are true about using the t- test in statistics

OPTION.A: The two groups compared have similar variances
OPTION.B: The population from which is drawn is normal in to some extent,
OPTION.C: Data is measured on at least an interval scale
OPTION.D: The score is measured separately in each group
OPTION.E: The target population standard deviation is unknown

49.EXPLANATION: These are standard assumptions for t-test application.

50.QUESTION: The following statements about confidence interval is not true

OPTION.A: Conventionally 95% confidence level is commonly chosen
OPTION.B: It tells us how much an exposure affects the subjects
OPTION.C: It detects significant and non-statistically significant effects
OPTION.D: It reveals the level of significance used
OPTION.E: It is similar to p-value

50.EXPLANATION: CI does not directly measure effect size; it is different from p-value.
